name: Reassembly
description: A spaceship building and universe-exploration game. Collect resources, expand and grow your fleet, and conquer your personal galaxy. Stellar ambience by Peaks.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows XP Processor: 2 GHz Dual Core Memory: 2 GB RAM Graphics: OpenGL 2.1 Storage: 150 MB available space
recommended_requirements: OS: Windows 7 Processor: 2.3 GHz+, Quad Core Memory: 2 GB RAM Graphics: OpenGL 3.3+, 256MB+ Storage: 250 MB available space

reviews.review_text: Upon trying this out, I really did not know what to expect. At first, however, I found myself a little lost in this strangely organic world that is somewhere in the far reaches of space.          YouTube™ Video:  Reassembly - Let's Play - Episode 1 - Getting started in this bizarre but fascinating world!

If you like Battleships Forever or Captain Forever, this game is for you. (They're both freeware so go try them if you're interested in this.) It takes the concepts of both, and throws in a bit of Starsector (namely the fleet mechanics) for good measure to make a game I've poured hours into already. (As of writing, I've played it for 10.8 hours. I bought it yesterday.)  While some have also compared it to Gimbal, I'd say only at the very start. The comparison starts losing ground once you get the bigger ships.  Where this stands out is the.. well, game. BF and CF are both fun for a short play, but don't have many backing gameplay mechanics. Reassembly gives you economies, waring fations, fleet control and quite a bit of variety (Though I'd like to see mod support in the future for even more pieces/factions). Each faction also plays differently in various ways, for example, one can plant and grow their own resources, but seem to be lacking in firepower, another has literal nukes, but no shields, and so on, it forces a change in tactics when it comes to ship design that keeps things fresh. With all that in mind, it's still a sandbox, outside of the tutorial, what you do is purely up to you with zero guidance, I personally like that, some might not.  It should also be noted it seems to run superbly. I have a fairly powerful machine, but any game with 1000s of ships/particles will slow it down some. This doesn't, I've had fleets of hundreds of ships facing off against each other, and it has stayed at a stable 60fps.   All in all, one of the best games I've purchased in a very long time.  EDIT: Apparently mod support is already somewhat in the game. I got ahead of myself.

Awesome game! You can build ships to your liking and adept your fleet to the situations at hand. It is very satisfying to equip a horde of drone minions and take them into battle against ships designed by other players that appear as agents in the game.  9.5/10

Love this game, all of the people here can simply explain how great this game is but a few things I must point out just to help you: -Don't go into the wormhole until you are powerful enough; the first world is designed to have agents (player made fleets) to be weak power levels, stronger than you from the start but still relatively weak in general. The moment you leave to the next world, you'll be fighting random power varieties of fleets so be warned -Objectives don't need to be done right away, take your time, agents don't need to die immediately and if you lose, go somewhere else, gather and build and become stronger -To make REALLY GOOD SHIPS requires a lot of time building, to where I spend 50% of the time building and fine tuning and 50% of the time playing. Not all good ships are required to be blocky and ugly.

Reassembly is both awesome, and not. If you enjoy ship builder games this game has a decent amount of options to do so. However, if you like in depth ship builders, Reassembly isn't a complex ship building simulator.  Essentially the game amounts to getting resources, selling resources, and building bigger ships. There is an 'Agent' mechanic which spawns other player made groups into your galaxy. Many of these squadrons will crush you until you can get to the very end game. These squadrons are really the only threat when you're powerful enough, so you either can leave them on and be demolished repeatedly until the end game, or turn them off and have a very boring end game.  It doesn't take long to get to the end game, and it's easy to run out of stuff to do. The best way to fight is to stack on piles of armor (it has no point value, so you can have as much as you'd like depending on how slow you don't mind your ship to be) and piling on a ton of a single effective weapon (most races have one or two weapons that are extremely effective, and a pile of flavor weapons which are functional against the standard ships, but not overly so against agents).  All in all it's a strangely balanced game, but I've had fun playing it. I'd say it's worth the price tag attached to it. If you need a ship builder simulator which has a lot of action but not a lot of depth, try Reassembly.
Designing ships is real cool, and destroying other people's ships with those ships is also real cool.

Its like that classic asteroid ship game with the triangle and the asteroids, but instead you can design your own triangle into a capital triangle and fight other triangles with giant triangle fleets while trying not to accidently smack into asteroids with your face.

This is a giant sandbox top down builder/shooter. You design your ships and stations then head out to conquer the galaxy. I'm not sure how each race works, two of them seem useless, and another two seem endgame only.. Maybe I'm missing something when trying to figure out what they are for.  If you love topdown sandbox shooters where you build your fleet and have amazing lightshows... I mean lazer fights! Then grab the game, I've got my money's worth already and am still enjoying it.  Build ships that look like things (beatles, scorpions, star destroyer, etc. Blow stuff up and enjoy the lightshow, at this price how can you say no?!

I can't wait to see what comes out in the future. Right now in it's stage, I would reccomend to a friend with a 10/10.

Gets pretty dull after a few hours when you are pretty high up, but those hours before that are highly fun. Much of the territory control/claiming is obtuse and not easy to plan. But if you like creative builders and space fights then this is a good game.  I generally count a game as being worth the price if I get 1 hour's fun per £1. I got this on sale, so got plenty of enjoyment out of it.

Reassembly is a decent sandbox shooter that has a relaxed atmosphere. The best part, obviously, is building your own ships and experimenting with designs. As you gather resources you can purchase better parts. Each of the factions have a unique theme and require different strategies to design. The ship building interface is very intuitive and easy to use, which is a big plus.   It's a nice, chill single player game but I think overall it lacks depth, which I will describe below. There's really no need for specialization against any particular foe. With such flexibility in ship design I was hoping this game could push this concept more. Once you have a decent ship it works against all factions almost universally. You can fiddle with designs for a while, but in the end, more expensive parts will make you better. With many factions it's quickest to destroy enemy ships for resources, so that becomes your sole focus. Once you max out your ship, basically nothing stands in your way. Unless you tried to get all the Steam achievements, like I did, there's not much of an end game to keep you playing. I spent most of my time on this game grinding out achievements.   In conclusion, it was fun but lack of depth put me on the fence on this one. After getting all of the achievements, I feel like I tapped out all of my reasons to keep playing. I would have liked to see the ship building aspect developed further. I'm leaning on the fence to recommend this game, but it was still fun for the time being. If you feel like this game might be something you'll be interested in then you'll probably enjoy it.
Amazing game. Just about everything you could possibly want in a ship building game.
Crazy delicious. One hit off this pipe and you're hooked.
I don't often post reviews for games.   You're doing yourself a disservice by not having this jewel in your library.

Absolutely great fun. This game reminds me of 'From the Depths' and 'Running with Rifles,' both of which I also recommend.  The 'vector' graphics are easy on the eyes, and the in-game universe really feels like a warzone, with various factions vying for territory. In it, you are like a general and engineer at the same time. You start as a weakling, a small ship of your faction trying to seize victory whenever possible, and through your efforts, you rise in power; become wealthy, with a mothership capable of constructing an entire fleet. A rags-to-riches story, but in space. I love it.

This game is horribly addictive. The basics: build your ship out of a set of parts and unlock new parts and weapons. This works so well that it got me playing 3 days straight without even touching another game. Players unlock new factions by killing capital ship from the latter and there are plenty of mods extending existing factions or adding new ones.  The gameplay is simple, weapons can be bound to mouse buttons or auto-fire, every faction has its specialities and different blocks with different stats and forms, the game seems quite balanced at the moment, I played 6 factions to max and did not yet encounter problems with balancing.  Graphics are simplistic but beautiful, the soundtrack is hypnotic and does not get annoying and there is a lots of physics involved, the game may slow down a bit during heavy battles.  This game gets a whopping 9.5 out of 10 for making everything it wants right.

Creativity and action! So fun designing your own ship. Spend as much time designing ships as you do playing. You can have a factory on your ship and make a fleet of your own creations!  No useless diplomicy. Just kill whatever is not you and take their resourses to build more.  Physics! Put engines all over your ship if you want to turn or break well. Mass means something so be careful how much hull you use.   10/10 Living starships that regrow.

Reassembly is the game I never knew I wanted, but man, did I want it badly.  A 2D top-down shooter not unlike space invaders or asteroids in the sense that you fly around and shoot stuff. Reassembly takes it to a whole new level, allowing you complete customization of your ship. You can connect various parts, which snap together at points like legos, to create whatever your mind can come up with. At the beginning of a playthrough, your ships will be small and fairly weak, but as you advance you will be able to fly massive frigates followed by your very own custom fleet.  One of my favorite parts of ship creation is the physics of thruster placement. Where you put your thrusters actually matters a lot; your ship won't be able to turn very well if you only place them on the back. This also lets you build some funny creations such as ships that travel by spinning. It also means that if you are having trouble progressing, you can completely change the feel of your vehicle by moving or adding a thruster.  Creation aside, the game revolves around the aquisition of currency (called 'C') and resource (called 'R'). You get both of these basically by blowing up your enemies, the other ship factions. You use your C to buy upgrades and new parts for your fleet, allowing you to take on bigger enemies. If you manage to conquer your whole galaxy, no big deal, the game allows you to jump into a wormhole to enter a new galaxy with your fleet. You can also unlock new factions to play as; all of them utilize different base shapes for their ships, meaning you can create entirely new ideas playing one faction that you couldn't with another.  If you feel like you've peaked, you can upload your fleet, sending it to other players' games as a powerful opponent called an Agent. This is a really great part of the game, it keeps things challenging and fresh.  Overall, I put this game in the same circle as Spore. You create cool things and share it with others. The game is fun to look at, very colorful, and it has an awesome soundtrack. If you like building things, if you like space, or you like shooting the hell out of ships, just go buy Reassembly.

Reassembly is a game that has grown on me.   I helped back it in it's early alpha days, giving its kickstarter my $30 donation. I liked the look of it. Sandboxish, procedural generation, top-down arcade feel. I played the very early alpha version and was entertained for a few hours. I soon lost interest, and the game became stale to me.  Since then I've come back to the game again and again. It's one of those games you'll get pumped about and think about all day only to come home from work and play it till you drop. It's enjoyment for me comes in short bursts.  Recently I've made a discovery. The game does not play itself. People complain about how tedious it is to capture systems and hold them. They say something along the lines of 'Once you capture it there is no point. Your ships don't spawn there and you get no resources.' Now listen here, that is where you are wrong.  You can build space stations that bristle with defenses and hold their own agains enemy capital ships. Alternatively, that space station can be covered in solar arrays to slowly farm you resources. Recently one of my favorite things to do is populate enemy territory with little 'Outpost' stations via a factory on one of my ships. I then spend time fighting on the front line with my fleet to push the enemy out. This game is all about how you play it.  In summary, Reassembly is a great game. It's hard to find anything else out there even close to it (I think of S.P.A.Z. as the only other game that resembles it, another great by the way). Keep giving it a chance and you'll get a lot of replayability out of it. If you enter with a closed mind you'll get a closed off experiance. I highly recommend it.

Reassembly is, in a nutshell, spaceship editing and combat done right. The editor is a snap to do just about whatever you want to do. For example, you can copy your ship and stick the new one on the front of your original ship in less than 5 seconds if you're even halfway decent at using the keybindings. Another good thing is that you can change reassembly from a miminalistic game to a Tron-esque visual style, allowing you to run Reassembly on an old or new computer and use whatever RAM you have. And if you're STILL not convinced, it has mods. Overall, Reassembly gets a 19/20. If you're on the fence about it, buy it on sale for the price of three chocolate bars.

*Full disclosure key given by developer*   This game is an absolute blast to play! I would most definitely recommend to any gamer! And not to mention this game will support mods which will take this game to the next level! Very excited to see what this game will become in the near future! Pick it up!

It's like good old 'Asteroids', but with lego SPACESHIPS you've designed yourself. Except there are half a dozen different building sets, each with a completely different meta. Long vs short range guns, one fraction can grow it's own space plants for resources, another has no shields and hulls you must build from Penrose tiles!  Progress up from piloting nifty little fighters, through hardy brawlers, up to god-like monster ships with 100 strong halos of LASER drones, chewing up enemies to birth a fleet of self-(re)assembling ships out your rear end, all of your own design! Deep emergent game play that's immensely gratifying and dusted with sci-fi references to movies, TV and space opera novels. The most perfectly suited geekery I've ever experienced. :o)  The 'tournament' feature is basically Gratuitous Space Battles, with easier controls, where you can pit anyone's designs against each other in a space arena. The over-all experience of the main game is basically what Spore should have been; expanding out smoothly from the tidal pool stages. One of the few things that sometimes irked me is when friendly ships zip in and nab your loot from under your nose. I would have been tempted to make this game entirely RTS oriented, with truly conserved resources (shared within your faction). But the design is definitely spot-on as it is: putting you in the action and keeping the simulation scale (almost) within the capabilities of (my) PC hardware. It's interface is minimalisticly simple and pieces snap together in an impressively accurate anticipation of what you intend. It all lubricates that design, test, refine loop, preserving a perfect mental 'flow' state until all hours of the morning...
Marvelously fun game. The AI is solid and there are hours of fun to be had.

There is about 15 hours of gameplay here that involves nothing more than shooting stuff. Recommended for what it is, a space shooter, though it could be a lot more if it involved some objectives or quests or loot or ANYTHING more than just shooting. The ship builder is very cool at the beginning, but eventually gets quite stale when you realize that all designs are armor on the outside and everything else on the inside. X of this, Y of that, etc. Would be better if there were some proximity bonuses to make the designs require more thought. Mods help flesh the game out a bit more, but none offer what is most needed: more stuff to do.

Hangs occassionally and you may need to restart the game, but if you look beyond that you'll see a great space shooter concept that's shaping up to be something awesome. Fortunately the devs are hard at work to fix and optimize the game. Reassembly features simple yet wicked vector style space combat, inclusive of the ability to build and upgrade your own ships with a beautiful, galaxy-inspired soundtrack. 7/10

Wow, where to even start. Amazing game, great expandability/modability. Piloting is pretty standard for top-down space games (good options for control schemes though), but game expands into fleet control where you can spawn or commandeer other ships around you, bring them all into battle. Best of all, every ship is customizable, and there are different factions with unique ship styles and looks, and once again, everything is added to by modders. Amazing!

While I already know it from the kickstarter, I didn't think much of it. It looked like a fun little arcade shooter. Something to keep you busy for a while, nothing more, nothing less.    I was COMPLETELY WRONG.   Reassembly is much deeper than you'd suspect, offering many hours of gameplay due to its well-executed procedural generation, plenty of weapons and a dozen factions. Although the game lets you roam free immediately after the short but very good tutorial (it teaches you all the basics while still letting you free to do as you please, and you'll have to learn the rest by playing), there is more than enough to do. You can build a sizeable fleet, design perfect ships, take over all space stations, wipe a faction off the map, destroy asteroid fortresses, take down strong fleets created by other players, or warp to an entire new map with your fleet.  Combine the simple, yet deep and very addictive gameplay with the amazing, trance electro music and the colourful, pleasing graphics, and you've got a great game for a great price.  I absolutely recommend it as long as you like top down / twin stick shooters and constantly tweaking your ship designs.

Arcade-style graphics.  Design your own ships. The part shapes are just occasionally odd enough that getting things to line up becomes part of the fun.  Test designs by letting them autopilot versus random other designs. Center of gravity and healing rate are important. Some ships are practically a huge gun with a seat and thrusters strapped onto it!  I spent hours not even playing - just designing a ship and watching it play against other designs in the test phase.  Once you are happy with a design (or just want to shoot something yourself) go in and harvest resources where the bad guys are, which also allows building up a fleet to team up against opponents. Building a fleet is pretty cool - although they are something like a herd of cows... not too smart and they get stuck in the weeds sometimes. Playing the fleet dynamics is a whole game by itself!  The flight is very space-like where you have to oppose thrust to slow down, which makes it feel very swimmy (I think why they say welcome to the tide-pool). In that regard it feels a little like Spore's bacterial stage, only flying takes much more concentration.  Replay value is sky-high, as optimizing ship designs at all size allowances allows starting over and trying new ideas.  Also, the game feels very different than other games because you have complete control how your ship handles (although once it's damaged and your engines have fallen off it will handle very differently until it heals again over several seconds, relatively fast). Trying to control a damaged ship reminds me of Robocraft, though this game is much more twitchy.   TLDR:  If I had to pick a favorite game so far in 2015, this might be it. The gameplay is straightforward. There are always more things to want to try out, which takes time to get there and try them. And Space feels alive. This is more of a tadpole simulator than a space game.

Despite anything in the game that feels familiar, I have never played anything quite like Reassembly.  You might describe it as a mish-mash of SPAZ, Spore, and some other top-down space shooters, but the similarity ends there. The procedurally generated 'galaxy' is full of varied enemies and dangers, and if you run out of baddies, you can dive into a wormhole for a fresh world. Wormholes have another use, more on that below.  The main draw of the game though is the ability to build your own ships. The ship editor is easy to learn, and has enough geometric shapes to allow you to produce anything you want. The playable factions have different available hull and weapon choices, making each one it's own playstyle. There is a progression curve, you must spend money earned in the world to unlock new weapons and increase the power cap limiting how much goes on your ship. It doesn't take too long to max it out though, allowing for huge many-beweaponed designs. You can also build space stations, it's as simple as building something with no thrusters and at least one factory.  Once you have some custom ships you like, hit up a wormhole. Instead of following it to a new world, you can choose to upload a copy of your fleet roster while staying in your own world. This uploaded fleet will then start randomly appearing in other players worlds. These are called Agent fleets, and fighting other people's creations that appear in your world can be challenging and exciting. I've encountered ships that were nearly unbeatable, forcing me to change my ships and tactics in order to prevail.  You needn't fly solo in your world either, you can equip a factory block and spend resources you collect to spawn AI controlled ships from your collection. I'm not sure if there's a limit to how many ships you can have at once, I've gotten up to about 15 or so, plus a hundred or so drones if I'm in my Galactica carrier. Tearing around space with a dozen ships blasting anything you target is super effective.  A caveat to mention is that there isn't any actual multiplayer, which would be great if it were possible, I can see why it would be difficult with all the physics objects that can occur. Maybe a sequel could pull it off. Also there are situations that cause the game to slow down significantly, particularly in Spikey Plant sectors once they start firing projectiles all over the place.  Many games out there let you build things, which is fine, but this is one of the few that lets you use and enjoy the fruits of your labor in actual gameplay. The vector-style graphics are used to good effect and really get my nostalgia going. I've only owned the game a couple weeks and have dumped almost 50 hours into it. It's got good music too.  Grade A most excellent game 8000/10
This game is simpily amazing. 420,000/10

A big old box of toys to play with in a huge, endless sandbox. A hell of a lot of game here if you like building and blowing spaceships up. Looks simple on the outside, but there's plenty of experimentation and customization at your fingertips. Exceptional title, I bought it on a whim and have been hooked since. The 'agent' system just adds to the fun, as players can upload their ships to spawn in other players' games, and it's these agent fleets that will give you the most trouble, and possibly the most inspiration in designing your fleet, which you will undoubtedly send into a wormhole to bring hot death to others. Fun stuff.

This game rocks. It sucked me in completely for a couple of weeks. I'd look up at the clock and think omg it's been 6 hours! I'd go to work the next day on 5 hours sleep. It stirred my gamer blood! The ship building freedom is top notch. You build any kind of ship you want particle by particle and there are lots of smart, handy features in the ship building editor to save time. You can hold down the mouse and drag it across an area to select multiple components or you can just double click one piece and everything attached to it will be selected.   A quick ship building tip is to just build one side of the ship, say a wing, select all the pieces then hit c to copy. Move the cursor to a blank part of the screen and hit v to paste, then hit m to mirror (to invert the selection). Now you can just attach that perfectly mirrored section onto the opposite side of the ship if you need symmetry like for wings. Symmetry is also important in placing your thrusters. You are in space so your ship isn't going to stop moving unless it crashes into something...or you put thrusters pointed in the opposite direction to the direction you're traveling in so you can break! Also each different playable faction has some unique pieces to build with. Sometimes the minor differences aren't obvious, like where pieces don't have as much mass as other factions or they have slightly higher armor, but when you stack all those pieces together into a ship then the net values really make a difference in speed, toughness, or resource carrying capacity. You'll want to look at the stats on the ship pieces closely if you're into ship building. If you're not into ship building there are premade ships available with each faction that you can use and just modify to your taste.  The game is beautiful to look at and very organic. To me it looks more like the world under a microscope filled with living, evolving organisms than it does a space frontier. Much like organisms, the ships actually create children. You can set a creation queue for yourself once you have a factory as part of your design. But you can also go into command mode by hitting tab and click on an allied vessel that has a factory and drag child designs into their queue so you begin to shape the future of your factions expansion without actually managing the execution. Just hit tab again to go back into pilot mode and go on your way. The allied ship you just programmed will now create what you set for it via the AI.   Once you've got your perfect fleet together you can find then fly into a wormhole. You will be given an option to follow it or stay. If you stay a parallel version of your fleet will upload to infect another player's galaxy through one of their wormholes while you remain where you're at with your original fleet. I just really wish there was some way of knowing how successful these invasions were, like a scoring system players could access to get some sense of how good your designs were.  The tournament mode doesn't pit you against other players. It just lets you test your own ships against your own designs and a small selection of premade designs. I would love to see a true tournament mode where you download player agents and test your ship against theirs with scoring. The game lacks true player interaction in real time but atleast we can see other player's creations as they come into our own galaxy as enemy agents controlled by the AI.  Unfortunately I do think there is a balance issue that needs to be addressed with faction 4. You will eventually find certain enemy agents that are typically oblong, travel at high speed, and shoot enormously long particle rays at you at range even from off of the screen! That's faction 4. They almost made me rage quit because they really get too many advantages, but I perservered and went back to the design editor. Their weakness is maneuverability. Their big bad weapon of choice is not turreted so the whole ship has to turn to target you with the death ray. This is not a huge disadvantage because their ships are inordinately fast but if you build a ship that can quickly side step their line of fire and either swarm them or ram them so that they can't turn into you then you can take them down...if you can catch them. Trapping them against asteroids is a typical ploy. Really though, no other faction gives nearly so much trouble...  The only other criticism I have is lag. No it's not really just a hardware issue. I play many other games where it's not an issue. The devs themselves have stated that they've worked really hard on the optimization but the fact is there comes a point where there are so many collisions going on in the galaxy that it can be taxing. I have loved this game since I got it.  The game is a simple and fun top-down space shooter with the ability to design and fly your own space ships, and even design an entire fleet with ships ranging from small shuttles and fighters to large destroyers and frigates.  There are several different races (some of which you can't play) that unlock while playing (and destroying stations from a race you haven't unlocked before), each with their own technological pro's and con's, but they are all (reasonably) evenly matched, and where one race falls short in say shield technology, it makes up for armor or speed.  The universe is generated in sectors each controlled by the majority of whatever ships are in that sector, so it can at times be hard to claim a sector completely when there is just 1 little core still floating about. The universe is limited in size, but thats alright since flying over one edge of the map puts you at the opposite side without a teleport or cheap backend trick. Watch out for pirate fleets though; These are, from what I gather, uploaded by other players and are randomly selected, which means that in one universe you may find ships you won't encounter in the next. This uploading is done through anomalies called wormholes that allow you to upload your fleet (designs) or fly to another universe. The latter will generate a new universe for you while you keep your resources, credits and ships.  The only downside I experienced so far is not being able to destroy core blocks from certain stations. Usually this happens after a few hours of playing and may be memory related, but other than that it plays like a dream. The thing about player created content worries me a bit though, but we'll see how well balanced the game is over time.  A definate recommendation and big thumbs up for this gem.

Have you ever played a game with spaceships and wanted to tweak the design a little? 'Why did they build it THAT way?' you wonder. Well, now you can find out if you have what it takes to be a (fictional) spaceship designer. You've got to grow your faction to control the galaxy, and you do it by building up a fleet of custom designed ships of every conceivable size. Seven playable factions use different components and combat styles. Another interesting twist is that there are 'agents,' special ships that are player-designed that get shared over the net when you go through a wormhole. Beware the agents, for they are deadly!  Reassembly is a fascinating mix of cerebral ship design and combat strategy, mixed with arcade shooter action as you put those designs to work. I recommend you read one of the game guides to get a feel for the game and get started on the right foot.

This is a solid and fun game that combines space shooter elements with a sand box and ship design. The fact that you can both upload your designs to appear in other players' universes and encounter theirs as roaming and often deadly 'agents' along with the game's 7 inherent playable factions (there are some non-playable ones as well) plus workshop support make this game a lot of fun.  You start with a simple small ship but you can unlock both more systems to build with and larger ships via combat and resource gathering and can unlock the other factions via battle so you can try their unique playstyles in future games. The best part of the game's factions is that while they all have some similiarities, they are quite diverse and not simply reskins of each other. Playing the starting Terran faction is quite different from the Reds which are different from the Sentinels and so on.  You eventually get to build ships from your ship and can keep them with you or release them and they'll defend areas as your control expands. Your AI allies will even build copies of your ship and you can use the interface to affect their production queues.  You also have a lot of control options and can even set how your weapons are keyed so you can fire every weapon via the LMB or put even big cumbersome weapons on point defense duty if you like. There's a lot to love here.  Heartfelt recommendation from me.

I like this game, but it gets stale very quickly and the developer didn't deliver on the promises made during early access. The game is exactly the same as it was when it came out on Steam, with the only major addition being a 'tournament' mode where you plop a couple ships into a ladder to see which one wins out.  The aesthetic is interesting, but ultimately the actual game is shallow. Most of the gameplay comes from designing your ship and seeing how it fares in combat, but the combat is doesn't have strategic depth other than ramming or kiting. Your design slowly moves away from what you'd call an actual spaceship and more towards a geometric shape with internal engines. A basic square filled with as many weapons and shields as possible is simply better than trying to create anything that's actually interesting. Ship combat, therefore, devolves into a blob of shields mounted on a square careening through space and slamming into other blobs of shields in an orgy of lasers and missiles. It looks nice, but carefully designing a ship isn't worth the effort.  The design system is simple and easy to understand, but in practice it just falls flat.  The 'living world' is also not really what you'd expect. Capturing territory across the galaxy becomes an exercise in Exterminatus from Warhammer 40,000. You bring as many ships as possible and cleanse every single enemy ship from an area of the map, which then switches colour to your faction. That's it. You don't get any resources, your own ships don't start to spawn there, not even a message appears on screen. A part of the map changes colour, and you move on to the next area. Eventually this devolves into chasing one tiny little gnat of a ship that can't even hurt you across your territory because it keeps reclaiming tiles. It's tedious.  Don't get me wrong, I liked this game, but it is very shallow and the replayability just isn't there.
